entry.title: Some handy shell tricks I recently learned
entry.content:
Last week I discovered a couple of really handy shell tricks which I now use.

Double BANG

This first one I got off another developer I was pairing with at work. !! <ENTER> can be used to reference the previous command which was executed. It can also be used with other commands e.g. cat $(!!). So far the only real use for it I've found is if you've typed a command and then realised you needed to run it with sudo. For this you'd use sudo !! <ENTER>.

Double ESC

This brings us to the other, more useful, shortcut I learned which I found by accident when trying to ESC something. <ESC> <ESC> will give you the last command you typed, just with sudo prepended onto it. If you've already started typing a command and then realise you need sudo at the start, <ESC> <ESC> will add that for you and allow you to continue writing your command. Ever since I discovered this shortcut I have literally used it every day.

It's worth noting that I'm using oh-my-zsh with quite a few plugins, and I could only get the !! shortcut to work using Bash.

entry.title: Syntax Tests
entry.content:
I'll now test some syntax highlighting.

Clojure

1
2
(defn my-function [param1 param2]
      {:b 45 :v "asdf"})

Bash

1
2
3
4
echo "hi"
if [[ -f "/usr" ]]; then
   echo "yay"
fi

entry.title: Tech Digest #1
entry.content:
New Segment

I'm starting this new segment as a means of storing and documenting any quality software development related resources I find. I often find extremely interesting or helpful resources which I like to share with others, so hopefully with this new segment some of them will pique the interest of other developers also.

Software Development

  • Saving a Project and a Company - Jacques Mattheij

Clojure

  • Lexical vs Dynamic Scope in Clojure - Chris McBride
  • 5 Faces of Dependency Injection in Clojure - Matthew Smith
  • (Now former) Java developer sneaks up on Clojure - Marko Bonaci
  • Why Boot is Relevant For The Clojure Ecosystem - Martin Klepsch

Blogging

  • Blogging on GitHub
  • Syntax Highlighting in Jekyll With Rouge - Sacha Schmid

Talks

  • Rich Hickey's Greatest Hits - The Changelog

entry.title: Helpful ClojureScript resources
entry.content:
Tutorials

  • modern-cljs

Books

  • ClojureScript: Up and Running - O'Reilly

Frameworks

  • Reagent - Minimalistic interface to ReactJS. The Reagent Cookbook and the Reagent Template are available to help you learn Reagent and set up your Reagent projects.
  • Quiescent - Another lightwith interface to ReactJS.
  • Om - A much heavier interface to ReactJS than Quiescent and Reagent, but provides many more features.
  • Gyr - An interface to AngularJS. An example can be found here.

Documentation & Tools

  • Austin REPL - A ClojureScript REPL which is quick and easy to use and provides a bunch of useful utilities.

entry.title: My Emacs setup
entry.content:
I've been learning how to use Emacs for several months for Clojure development. I thought I would document my initial setup here and continue updating it as I find new packages and develop more useful/convenient keybindings. You can also find my up to date .emacs.d in my dotfiles GitHub repo.

I tried various starter kits such as Prelude, Emacs Starter Kit and Emacs Live. I eventually settled with Emacs Live for a couple of months. After getting frustrated while trying to (unsuccessfully) modify the Emacs Live setup, I started looking for other options. I then stumbled on oh-my-emacs. Oh-my-emacs provides you with a completely documented starting setup which benefits both beginners and experts of Emacs. It's configuration is contained within .org files which contains Emacs Lisp code within #+BEGIN_SRC and #+END_SRC tags. The .org files get parsed into .el files during Emacs initialisation, and you can prevent snippets of Emacs Lisp code from being parsed by changing #+BEGIN_SRC emacs-lisp to #+BEGIN_SRC emacs-lisp :tangle no.

Installation:

  • Mac: Emacs Mac port
  • Linux: Your Linux distro's package manager will likely contain Emacs.

Setup:

Install oh-my-emacs by following these Quick Start steps.

The following requires updates…

Configuration:

  1. Add melpa archives

    1
2
     (add-to-list 'package-archives
              '("melpa" . "http://melpa.milkbox.net/packages/"))

  2. Mac user keys

    1
2
3
     (global-set-key (kbd "M-c") 'copy-region-as-kill)
 (global-set-key (kbd "M-v") 'yank)
 (global-set-key (kbd "M-z") 'undo)

  3. NeoTree

    1
     (global-set-key [f8] 'neotree-toggle)

  4. WindMove

    1
2
     (when (fboundp 'windmove-default-keybindings)
       (windmove-default-keybindings 'alt))

  5. Undo an undo

    1
     (global-set-key (kbd "C-S-/") 'undo-tree-redo)

  6. Fullscreen a frame

    1
     (global-set-key (kbd "C-c m") 'toggle-frame-maximized)

entry.title: Helpful Clojure resources
entry.content:
During my placement at Australia Post I spent a lot of time using Clojure. Clojure is a functional language on the JVM with LISP-like syntax. I've really enjoyed learning and using Clojure and, although I'm still learning, I've used some resources along the way which I think are great for Clojure beginners.

Setup

  • Light Table - A good IDE for learning Clojure.
  • Emacs - Alternatively, you can start off using Emacs. It has a higher learning curve but is highly configurable and works really well with Lisp-based languages.
  • Leiningen - Tool for easy Clojure project and dependency management (mandatory).

Tutorials

  • Learn X in Y Minutes - Quickest way to get a brief understanding of Clojure syntax.
  • puredanger's Tutorial - Written by an active Clojure contributer.
  • Brave Clojure - Very extensive but sometimes a little hard to follow.
  • Fast Track Clojure
  • Destructuring Tutorial/Reference

Challenges

  • 4clojure
  • Clojure Koans
  • Exercism - Exercises for 19 different languages, including Clojure.
  • Project Euler - Language agnostic, but these challenges taught me a lot about how to solve algorithms in a functional way vs imperative.

Books

  • Programming Clojure - Pragmatic Programmers
  • Clojure Programming - O'Reilly
  • Clojure Cookbook - O'Reilly

Web Development

  • Clojure Web Dev - A great introduction to web development in Clojure. Contains a very informative talk about building a backend supported web application, and includes code snippets and resources for further study.
  • What Web Framework Should I Use?
  • Luminus - A great Leiningen template for setting up skeletons of Clojure webapps with various component configurations. It's accompanied by some very informative docs which make learning web development in Clojure much easier.

Documentation & Tools

  • tryclj - An online REPL.
  • grimoire - One of the best online references for Clojure documentation.
  • Clojure Toolbox - An organised collection of useful libraries and tools for Clojure.
  • ClojureWerks - Another collection of quality Clojure libraries and their documentation.
  • Clojure Sphere - A listing of statistics for components in the Clojure ecosystem.
  • Clojure Docs - Community-powered clojure documentation.
  • lein-bikeshed - A Leiningen plugin which scans your project for bad code.
